item.title: Industrial Policy Is Back—And Minerals Are at the Center
item.description: The United States has revived its industrial policy playbook to support critical minerals through price floors, stockpiles, and equity. But in a sector shaped by geology, cost curves, and market risk, durable security depends on commercial viability—not just public capital.

item.title: How Would Iran Respond to a U.S. Attack?
item.description: If the United States strikes Iran, how will Tehran respond? History suggests a calibrated mix of cyberattacks, drones, maritime pressure, and limited missile strikes designed to signal resolve while avoiding a wider regional war.

item.title: Criminal Kingpin “El Mencho” Is Dead, What Comes Next?
item.description: CSIS Americas Program Director Ryan C. Berg and Henry Ziemer analyze the implications of criminal kingpin El Mencho's death at the hands of Mexican security forces.

item.title: The United States–Republic of Korea Alliance: Strengthening Extended Nuclear Deterrence in a Shifting Strategic Landscape
item.description: As new and enduring uncertainties shape the Indo-Pacific and the U.S.-ROK alliance, the Asan Institute and CSIS conducted a joint project to assess extended nuclear deterrence cooperation within the alliance and recommend ways to strengthen its credibility and resilience.
